query: For agricultural landscapes, what are the most effective interventions for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary:
Based on the evidence found, the most effective interventions for creating and managing aquatic habitats for amphibians in agricultural landscapes include pond creation, wetland creation, pond restoration, and ditch management. 

Pond creation for amphibians has shown consistently positive results across 28 studies. Amphibians used some or all created ponds in all studies, with 64-100% of created ponds being used and 64-68% supporting reproduction. Created ponds supported up to 15 naturally colonizing species and up to 10 breeding species. Success was influenced by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, and fish presence.

Wetland creation also proved effective, with 15 studies showing that 4-15 amphibian species used or colonized created wetlands. Created wetlands had similar or higher numbers of amphibian species and abundance compared to natural wetlands in 54% of studies reviewed, with success affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence, and distance to source wetlands.

Pond restoration showed mixed but generally positive results across 15 studies. Restoration increased amphibian species numbers, maintained or increased populations, and increased pond occupancy in multiple studies. However, one study found pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations.

Ditch management under agri-environment schemes significantly increased amphibian species numbers and abundance compared to conventionally managed ditches, with one UK study showing increased common toad numbers following ditch management.

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."

Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. One replicated controlled and paired study from the Netherlands found higher plant diversity on ditch banks along unsprayed edges of winter wheat compared to those sprayed with pesticides.

query: What interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians, such as refuges or hibernation sites?
relevant_summary: Several interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians. Artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites can be created to provide overwintering and dry-season shelter, with one UK study showing these structures were used by common frogs and smooth newts, while another found they helped maintain great crested newt populations when combined with other habitat management. Creating refuges using coarse woody debris has shown mixed results, with some studies finding no effect on overall amphibian abundance while others reported increased frog species in restoration projects that included reintroducing woody debris. Artificial refugia have been successfully used by translocated amphibians including Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders. Creating microclimate and microhabitat refuges is also mentioned as an approach, though specific details reference other habitat restoration techniques. Additionally, adding woody debris to ponds and creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats are potential interventions, though evidence for their effectiveness is currently lacking in the available research literature.

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of creating artificial refuges, hibernacula and aestivation sites on reptile populations. Three studies were in each of the UK and Australia, two were in New Zealand and one was in each of the USA, Spain and Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that areas with refuge logs had higher reptile species richness than areas without refuges.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that areas with refuge logs had a higher abundance of reptiles than areas without refuges.
Reproductive success (1 study): One study in the UK found that after translocating adders to an artificial hibernaculum, there was evidence of successful reproduction.
Survival (1 study): One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in New Zealand found that in areas with artificial refuges, survival of McCann’s skinks was similar to areas without refuges.

BEHAVIOUR (9 STUDIES)

Use (9 studies): Nine studies (including one replicated, controlled study and one randomized, controlled study) in the USA, the UK, Australia, New Zealand and Italy found that artificial refuges were used by reptiles, common lizards, adders, common geckos, species of skinks, and by an ocellated lizard to lay a clutch of eggs. Four of the studies also found that some reptiles showed a preference for refuges with certain designs or construction materials."

query: What factors and interventions have influenced the success of natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK?
relevant_summary: Research on natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK has identified several key factors and interventions that have influenced success. Translocation projects have shown varying success rates, with studies finding that translocated natterjack toads established breeding populations in 30-70% of cases, with re-establishing toads on dune or saltmarsh habitat being more successful than on heathland. Pond creation has been particularly effective, with five before-and-after studies showing that pond creation along with other interventions significantly increased natterjack toad populations or maintained/increased populations at 75% of sites. Habitat protection through statutory designation has also been shown to better protect natterjack toad populations compared to unprotected sites. Additional interventions include adding limestone to ponds to reduce acidification, with one study showing establishment of one of three translocated populations, and grazing management, with studies finding that habitat management including reintroduction of grazing helped maintain or increase natterjack toad populations. However, some interventions showed mixed results, such as reducing competition from native amphibians, which did not increase natterjack toad populations despite being implemented.

query: What are the general outcomes and challenges associated with captive breeding programs for different amphibian groups like frogs, toads, and salamanders?
relevant_summary: Based on evidence from amphibian conservation programs, captive breeding outcomes vary significantly across species. Studies show that 35 of 54 amphibian translocations (65%) resulted in established breeding populations, with programs releasing over 1,000 animals showing higher success rates. However, captive breeding faces substantial challenges: 30-88% egg hatching rates, 75% survival to metamorphosis, and only 17-51% survival as froglets in captivity. Some species successfully reproduce in captivity while others are difficult to maintain or raise to adults, with one review noting 17-50% of captive populations reproducing successfully. Head-starting programs show mixed results, with 6 of 10 studies establishing breeding populations, though survival rates remain low at 1-17% over four years. Environmental factors significantly affect success - reproductive success depends on temperature and simulated wet/dry seasons, while housing density and parental care affect development. Disease is a concern, with studies finding greater fungal loads in UV-boosted frogs. To improve outcomes, researchers recommend using surrogate species first to refine husbandry techniques before working with critically endangered species.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "captive breeding programs amphibians frogs toads salamanders"}

{
  "action_id": "881",
  "action_title": "Head-start amphibians for release",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-two studies head-started amphibians from eggs and monitored them after release.
Six of 10 studies (including five replicated studies) in Denmark, Spain, the UK and USA and a global review found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads. Two found mixed results with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites. Two found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population. For five of the studies, release of captive-bred individuals, translocation or habitat management were also carried out.
Nine of 10 studies (including nine replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully. One found adult survival was 1–17% over four years and one found limited breeding following the release of adults.
Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK and USA found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals. One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild. One replicated study in Australia found that corroboree frog tadpoles released earlier had higher survival, but metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.
Three studies (including one replicated study) in the USA only provided results for head-starting in captivity. Two found that Houston toad eggs could be captive-reared to tadpoles, but only one successfully reared adults. Three studies (including two replicated studies) in Canada and the USA found that during head-starting, amphibian growth rate, size, stress levels and survival was affected by the amount of protein provided, housing density or enclosure location. One found that mass, stress levels and survival were not affected by the amount of food or habitat complexity."
}

query: As an alternative to creating entirely new ponds, what actions can be taken to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians?
relevant_summary: Instead of creating new ponds, existing water bodies can be restored or enhanced for amphibians through several approaches. Pond restoration activities have shown mixed effectiveness, with fifteen studies finding that restoration sometimes increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or improved pond occupancy and breeding success (Action ID 878). Adding limestone to reduce acidification can help establish amphibian populations, with studies showing increased larval and egg survival for moor frogs, common frogs, and natterjack toads, though some cases also resulted in high tadpole mortality or abnormal eggs (Action ID 748). Removing tree canopy to reduce pond shading helped establish breeding populations of garlic toads following restoration (Action ID 758). Controlling fish populations by drying out ponds increased numbers of amphibian species and improved breeding success of frogs and newts (Action ID 826). Additionally, augmenting ponds with ground water to reduce acidification is suggested as a potential approach, though no studies have yet tested its effectiveness (Action ID 803).

query: Which vegetation management practices are most likely to benefit amphibian populations, and which are likely to be ineffective or harmful?
relevant_summary: Vegetation management practices that benefit amphibian populations include reducing mowing regimes, which increased frog species numbers in Australia (783), and raising mowing heights which was less damaging to amphibians (138). Prescribed forest fires showed mixed effects with most studies finding no impact or variable results depending on species and timing (877). Tree thinning had mixed to negative effects on amphibians (852), while leaving coarse woody debris showed no significant benefit for most species (843). Pond restoration with aquatic vegetation management was generally beneficial, increasing amphibian species numbers and populations in multiple studies (878).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "852",
  "action_title": "Thin trees within forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies (including four replicated and/or controlled studies) in the USA compared amphibians in thinned to unharvested forest. Two found mixed effects of thinning on abundance, depending on amphibian species and time since harvest. One found that amphibian abundance increased, except for ensatina salamanders. One found a negative overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians and one found that thinning did not affect abundance. A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, which included thinning with three other types, decreased salamander populations. One controlled, before-and-after site comparison study in the USA found that high volumes of pre-existing downed wood prevented declines in amphibian populations following thinning.
Four studies (including two replicated, controlled studies) in the USA compared amphibians in thinned to clearcut forest. Two found higher amphibian abundance, apart from ensatina salamanders, or a less negative overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians in thinned forest. Two found mixed effects on abundance depending on species, life stage and time since harvest. A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, which included thinning with three other types, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting.
One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used thinned forest a similar amount, or for one species more than unharvested forest and that emigrating salamanders, but not frogs, used it significantly more than clearcuts.
One site comparison study in the USA found that thinning decreased the body condition of ensatina salamanders 10 years after harvest."
}

{
  "action_id": "843",
  "action_title": "Leave coarse woody debris in forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that there was no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, but that the overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained.
Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance, but did reduce species richness in one study.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed.
One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas, and was similar in wood piles to unharvested forest."
}

{
  "action_id": "878",
  "action_title": "Restore ponds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of pond restoration for amphibians.
One replicated, before-and-after study in Denmark found that pond restoration had mixed effects on European tree frog population numbers depending on site. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations. Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One found that numbers of species did not increase. Two before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in Estonia found that pond restoration, along with terrestrial habitat management, maintained or increased populations of natterjack toads. One systematic review in the UK found that there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, which often included pond restoration, resulted in self-sustaining great crested newt populations.
One small, replicated study in the USA found that pond restoration had mixed effects on spotted salamander hatching success depending on restoration method.
One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that restoration increased the number of ponds used by breeding natterjack toads. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. Three before-and-after studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Denmark and Italy found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1–7 species, with 6–65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding."
}

query: What key factors are associated with the success or failure of amphibian colonization and breeding in newly created ponds?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from action documents, several key factors influence amphibian colonization and breeding success in newly created ponds. Studies found that pond age was a significant factor, with survival of translocated Oregon spotted frogs increasing with increasing age of created ponds (Action 865). Fish presence strongly affected success, with draining ponds to eliminate fish increasing numbers of amphibian species (Action 826). Vegetation cover was identified as important, with canopy removal shown to help establish breeding populations of certain species like garlic toads in one study (Action 758), though it did not increase hatching success of spotted salamanders in another. The permanence of created water bodies affected outcomes, with one study finding that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on pond permanence (Action 869). Distance to existing ponds influenced colonization success, along with surrounding landscape characteristics (Action 869). Reproduction rates varied significantly by species, with naturally colonizing frog species reproducing in 50-75% of created ponds, while translocated frog species reproduced in only 31% of ponds (Action 865). Salamanders showed similar variation, with alpine newts reproducing in 60-100% of created ponds (Action 867), while midwife toads reproduced in only 16% of created ponds (Action 868). Common toads and midwife toads naturally colonized 29-100% of created ponds (Action 868). Overall, colonization rates were high (64-100% for amphibians using ponds), but successful breeding was more variable (2-75% depending on species) (Action 869).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "869",
  "action_title": "Create ponds for amphibians",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."
}

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis?
relevant_summary: Evidence from multiple studies shows that direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis have varying effectiveness. Antifungal treatment (action 882) has the strongest evidence, with 12 of 16 studies finding that treatment cured or increased survival of infected amphibians. Itraconazole was particularly effective, with six of eight studies showing it cured amphibians of chytridiomycosis. Temperature treatment (action 770) was also effective, with four of five studies finding that increasing temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads. Antibacterial treatment (action 763) showed promise, with two studies finding that chloramphenicol cured green tree frogs and Archey's frogs, though trimethoprim-sulfadiazine only increased survival time without curing infection. Antifungal skin bacteria (action 764) had mixed results, with three of four studies finding no reduction in infection or death rates. Immunization (action 765) was ineffective, with one study finding vaccination did not reduce infection rate or mortality. Wild treatment (action 767) showed limited success, with one study finding that treating wild midwife toads reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis.

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of retaining habitat features like riparian buffers, coarse woody debris, and snags during timber harvesting?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents found, retaining habitat features during timber harvesting shows mixed effects across different wildlife groups. For riparian buffers, twelve studies found mixed effects on amphibian abundance depending on species and buffer width, with five studies finding that wider buffers generally supported greater amphibian numbers and species richness compared to narrower buffers. However, some studies found no difference in abundance between different buffer widths. Four studies found that abundance and species composition in buffered areas were similar to unharvested forest, while two found lower numbers than in unharvested areas.

For coarse woody debris retention, studies showed varied responses among different taxa. Two replicated studies found no significant difference in abundance for eight of nine amphibian species when woody debris was retained versus removed from clearcuts, though the overall amphibian response was more negative where debris was retained. However, one study found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts with retained woody debris more than those where it was removed, and another found significantly higher survival of juvenile amphibians in woody debris piles compared to open areas within clearcuts.

For snags/standing deadwood, one study found that leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not prevent decreases in salamander abundance or changes in species composition compared to unharvested areas. Another study found no difference in amphibian species numbers or abundance between removal or creation of dead trees within forests.

For mammals, three studies found mixed effects of coarse woody debris retention, with one study finding more small mammal species groups in felled areas with woody debris, while two studies found that retaining or adding debris did not consistently increase small mammal abundance across species.

For reptiles, two studies found mixed effects of adding snags and woody debris on diversity, species richness, and abundance compared to areas without debris manipulation. Variable retention management, which includes retaining these habitat features, showed that nine bird species occurred at higher densities compared to control stands, while five species were found at lower densities.

Abundance (3 studies): One out of three replicated studies (two controlled, one site comparison, one before-and-after) in Canada, the USA and Malaysia found that retaining or adding coarse woody debris did not increase numbers or frequency of records of small mammals. query: What actions are available to mitigate the impacts of agricultural pollution on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, several actions can help mitigate agricultural pollution impacts on amphibian populations. Managing ditches has shown positive effects, with one UK study finding increased common toad numbers and a Netherlands study showing higher amphibian species abundance in ditches managed under agri-environment schemes compared to conventional management (Action 749). Reducing pesticide, herbicide, or fertilizer use has also demonstrated benefits, with a Taiwan study finding that halting pesticide use combined with habitat management increased Taipei frog populations (Action 832). Creating wetlands provides another mitigation strategy, with 15 studies showing that created wetlands can support similar or higher numbers of amphibian species compared to natural wetlands, with 4-15 amphibian species successfully using or colonizing created wetlands in Kenya and the USA (Action 880). However, no evidence was found for the effectiveness of preventing pollution from agricultural lands entering watercourses (Action 802), establishing riparian buffers (Action 2882), creating artificial wetlands for pollution reduction (Action 2201), treating livestock wastewater (Action 2199), or establishing aquaculture for nutrient extraction (Action 2200).

query: How effective are conservation actions such as legal protection, habitat creation, and translocation for great crested newt populations in the UK?
relevant_summary:
Research on conservation actions for great crested newts in the UK shows mixed effectiveness. For translocation, studies found that four of six documented translocations maintained or established breeding populations, with newts present one year after release in 37% of cases. However, breeding failed in 48% of ponds within three years, and a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that translocation resulted in self-sustaining populations. Great crested newts reproduced following 56% of translocations, though some projects also included habitat management or head-started larvae release.

Habitat creation through pond construction showed more positive results. Studies found that naturally colonizing and translocated great crested newts established breeding populations at 57-75% of created ponds. Up to 88% of created ponds were colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing newts, with head-started newts reproducing in 38% of created ponds. However, similar to translocation, a systematic review found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including pond creation resulted in self-sustaining populations.

Regarding legal protection, evidence indicates significant limitations. Three reviews found that legal protection was not effective at protecting amphibian populations during development. While over 600 great crested newt mitigation licenses were issued over 10 years in England and Wales, this increase in licensing did not translate to effective population protection. Additional habitat management actions like creating refugia and artificial hibernacula showed some success, with one study maintaining four great crested newt populations through refuge creation combined with other interventions.

query: What management options are available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations?
relevant_summary:
Several management options are available to mitigate the impacts of timber harvesting on forest amphibian populations. Retaining riparian buffer strips during timber harvest is the most extensively studied approach, with twelve studies investigating its effectiveness for amphibians (Action ID: 747). Six studies comparing clearcutting with and without riparian buffer strips found mixed effects on abundance depending on species and buffer width, with one study finding significantly higher amphibian abundance with buffers. Eleven studies comparing harvested areas with retained buffers to unharvested forest found mixed effects depending on species or volume of existing downed wood, with some showing similar abundance and species composition to unharvested forest while others found lower numbers. Two of four studies found that wider riparian buffer strips had greater numbers of amphibian species and higher abundance than narrower strips.

Alternative harvesting methods can also help protect amphibians. Using shelterwood harvesting instead of clearcutting (Action ID: 3871) provides a more gradual habitat change. Group selection harvesting or thinning instead of clearcutting (Action ID: 3868) can help maintain forest structure. Patch retention harvesting (Action ID: 330, 3869) leaves some areas completely unharvested, providing habitat refuges. Selective or reduced impact logging instead of conventional logging (Action ID: 3867) can also minimize habitat disturbance.

Creating microclimate and microhabitat refuges (Action ID: 809) and leaving woody debris in forests after logging (Action ID: 3632) can provide important microhabitat features that amphibians need. Buffer zones around core habitat (Action ID: 850) can help protect critical areas, though one study found that 30 m buffer zones around wetlands were insufficient to protect marbled salamanders. Managing silviculture practices in plantations (Action ID: 792) can also be part of a comprehensive approach to amphibian conservation in managed forests.

query: What are the most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary:
The most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians include creating new ponds, restoring existing ponds, and restoring wetlands. Twenty-eight studies found that created ponds were successfully colonized by amphibians, with 64-100% of ponds being used and 64-68% supporting reproduction. Pond restoration showed positive effects in 15 studies, increasing species numbers and breeding success in multiple cases. Wetland restoration was effective in 17 studies, with 89% of cases showing similar or higher amphibian abundance compared to natural wetlands.

Fish control measures are crucial for amphibian success, including removing fish by drying ponds, catching, using rotenone, or installing barriers. These methods significantly increased amphibian species numbers, abundance, and breeding success in multiple studies. However, some fish control methods like rotenone can have negative effects on amphibians themselves.

Habitat connectivity is also important, with actions to maintain connectivity between habitat patches being beneficial. Other supportive measures include deepening ponds to prevent drying, removing tree canopy to reduce shading, and excluding domestic animals.

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using chemical treatments for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary:
Documented benefits of chemical treatments for amphibian conservation include: antifungal treatments cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis in 12 of 16 studies (including four randomized, replicated, controlled studies) across Europe, Australia, Tasmania, Japan and the USA. Six of eight studies found that treatment with itraconazole was effective at curing amphibians of chytridiomycosis. One study found that adding salt to a pond kept a population of green and golden bell frogs free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months.

Negative impacts documented include: four studies found that antifungal treatments did not cure chytridiomycosis, but only reduced infection levels or had mixed results. Six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians. Treating wild midwife toads with fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis. The evidence indicates that while some chemical treatments can be effective against chytridiomycosis, they may also cause significant negative side effects including death in treated amphibians.

query: As an alternative to treating infected individuals, what environmental management actions can help control chytridiomycosis in the wild?
relevant_summary: Several environmental management actions can help control chytridiomycosis in the wild. Adding salt to ponds has shown success, with one study in Australia finding that a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months following salt addition. Temperature modification is another effective approach, with four of five studies demonstrating that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis. Antifungal skin bacteria can be used, with one study finding that adding these bacteria to soil significantly reduced chytridiomycosis infection rates of red-backed salamanders. Pond drying combined with fungicidal treatment has been attempted, with one study finding this approach reduced infection levels in midwife toads but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis. Other potential environmental approaches include using zooplankton to remove chytrid zoospores, though no evidence was found for this method's effectiveness.
